title: Are there any Vikings living today? - Quora

response.answer_text: First, realise that Viking was an occupation, not a people. The Norse people, that is the Germanic tribal people of Scandinavia, would "go Viking" as a seasonal activity outside the more labour-intensive parts of the farming year. The Viking era ended when the kingdoms of Europe got well enough organised into central powers with well-organised militaries. These forces were strong enough to repel the more small-scale raids that the Vikings were good at. So, no, there are no Vikings today, as there are nobody sailing around Europe to raid unprotected churches. But the Norse people, genetically speaking, is still here in Scandinavia, Iceland and (in part) Finland and Russia. Oh, and I guess the genes were spread around the rest of Europe too, especially the British Isles and Northern France. The culture, however, has completely disappeared.

Why, yes of course—me for one:  Just joking. The term Viking is an oft misused word which in its day meant just those who voyaged afar to raid and pillage, just as others were builders, fishermen, farmers, weavers, etc. There are of course descendants of viking age Northmen but no true vikings in the accepted historical sense. The Viking Age pretty much ended in the 12th century as political and economic circumstances changed.

Viking was an Old Norse verb meaning to travel abroad on adventure, and vikingr was the noun for a person who did that. As Astrid says it was a job description as much as anything. Going ‘viking’ could be mean going on a trading mission, but it could also mean all the violent activities of piracy, looting and extortion that some Scandinavians became infamous for in the early middle ages. But it was a living; back in those days Scandinavia didn’t have much going for it in the way of farmland, the trading routes via the Baltic were in their infancy and no one had a clue what crude oil was, so armed robbery and extracting Danegeld with menaces was one of the few avenues to get rich or die trying. There are groups of people all over the world doing similar things today, we generally call them criminals.

The Vikings became us. Well, many of us in Europe and the US and Russia. The Vikings ventured to Russia, Finland, Ireland, France, the Mediterranean, Iceland, Greenland, and Vinland (North America). The Vikings settled down, married, had kids, and started families in the Danelaw. Those families are still there. The English were conquered by descendants of Rollo the Viking, who took up residence in Normandy. His people became the Normans, and took over all the manor houses in Anglo-Saxon England. The once-Viking-then-Norman people with French expanded the Anglo-Saxon language into English. If you are French, African-American, English, Sicilian, Spanish, or Russian, you could count the Vikings as one group among your ancestors.

Yes! Most people that have genetic roots in Scandinavia, northwest Europe, western Russia, the British isles, or Iceland…places the Vikings originated from or settled…are genetically the descendants of Vikings. This has recently been proven in scientific genetic studies. This includes many Americans, especially in Minnesota. We are the Vikings! In addition, about 40% of modern English is, or has origins in, Old Norse - the language the Vikings! Also, many of the traditions and values of the Vikings live on in our culture.
